para.text: Each archive must include a "readme.txt" and a modelgeoreft.txt file. The purpose of the

dialog box is to allow the user to edit the readme.txt and the modelgeoreft.txt files within ModelArchiver. However, the content of the readme.txt file is not stored as part of the ModelArchiver project.
for more information about the modelgeoreft.txt file.
The purpose of the readme.txt file is to explain the structure and content or the model archive and how to use it.
The readme.txt file should include the following

li.text: a description of the archive folder structure and of the files contained in each subfolder,
instructions for reconstructing the model archive from the downloaded model files, and
a brief description of each model run.

para.text: Additional items that might be included in the readme.txt file are

li.text: the citation of the journal article or USGS report related to the archive,
the citation of the data release,
citations for any programs included in the model archive,
the operating system used for the models, and
digital object identifiers for both the data release and the accompanying report.

para.text: If the "Automatically add file descriptions to readme.txt" checkbox on the

pane is checked, ModelArchiver will append descriptions of each file and folder to the text file that you specify. Many of the file descriptions will be assigned automatically. You can edit the automatically assigned descriptions if you don't like them. You will need to provide an overall description of the archive and its purpose. For each model in the archive, you also need to tell how to run the model. The file and folder descriptions are only appended when you actually create the archive and they will only be appended to the version of the readme.txt file that is copied to the archive.
The readme.txt file is intended to be read by humans, not machines. A machine-readable
file will also be created in a later step.
You need to include the Digital Object Identifier (DOI) in the readme.txt file so you may wish to reserve a DOI when first creating the readme.txt file. The
para.link: USGS Digital Object Identifier (DOI) Creation Tool
para.text: can be used to create DOIs for USGS products. Note that journal articles would typically be assigned a DOI by the journal.
